Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Biomechanics of Patterned Epithelial Chiral Morphogenesis

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to use a combination of micro-fabrication, live cell imaging, molecular assay, traction force measurement, and mathematical modeling to elucidate the biomechanical and biochemical mechanisms for epithelial chiral morphogenesis on micopatterned surfaces. Chirality, also known as handedness or left-right (LR) asymmetry, is well conserved in the development of living organisms. In vertebrate development, the formation of epithelial chiral structures (i.e., chiral morphogenesis) is biomechanically important in establishing the LR asymmetric body plan. Recently, we have recapitulated such chiral morphogenesis on micropatterned surfaces. Studies conducted under this award will evaluate the role of cell biomechanics in micropatterned cell chirality with experiments and numerical simulation, with the emphasis on single cell chirality and the effects of cell-cell interactions. In addition, important signaling pathways and cytoskeletal proteins will be identified and analyzed for their effects on epithelial chirality and cell mechanics.
This project presents a comprehensive effort to understand the biomechanical and biomolecular mechanisms of patterned epithelial chiral morphogenesis, which reflects a fundamental yet poorly understood cellular property and may directly relate to asymmetry in development and disease. If successful, the proposed research will (1) develop a new conceptual framework to study the chirality of cellular collective behaviors; (2) address the role of intracellular and intercellular mechanisms in determining multi-cellular LR asymmetry; and (3) initiate a new paradigm in research of LR asymmetry in development and diseases with an in vitro multicellular system. The educational plan focuses on course development in Cell Biomechanics at the undergraduate and graduate level as well as the outreach involving high school and undergraduate students. In addition, new initiatives will involve the development of artistic works to inform students and the general public of the importance of LR asymmetry in development and disease.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objectives of our project are to investigate the role of the intracellular cytoskeleton, cell-cell interaction, and geometric confinement in cell chirality (or handedness of the cell), and to identify important signaling pathways and cytoskeletal proteins that are important for epithelial chirality. In the past five years, with the support from the National Science Foundation, we have completed the project with a few major findings listed below. First, the chiral phenomena are typically first observed on the patterned boundaries. If cell-cell adhesion is strong, this chiral information can propagate deeply into the interior region that is far away from the boundaries. With impaired adhesion due to cellular processes such as the epithelial-mesenchymal transition, the chirality can be lost quickly in the space, with chiral biases only observed a few cells away from the boundaries.  Second, using advanced image processing techniques, we are able to identify new chiral markers, based on cellular and nuclear polarization on geometrically patterned surfaces.  Third, cell chirality can regulate cell-cell junction formation. Mismatch in cell chirality leads to impaired cell-cell junctions, compared to those between cells with the same chiral bias. Finally, through screening, we identify certain kinase (enzyme) that can reverse cell chirality and confirm the cytoskeletal origin of cell chirality. Overall, our study unveils the biomechanical and biophysical mechanisms associated with patterned cell chirality.

Our findings have broad impact in various fields including vascular permeability, cancer development, and embryogenesis. In the past, we have around ten papers published under the support of NSF. These seminal papers have built a solid foundation for others and us in the field to further study cell chirality in development and disease. The impact of our studies is much beyond the mechanisms revealed, and they will influence several fields of research in biology and medicine. With support from NSF, we have trained several graduate students, undergraduate students, and high school students.  We also disseminate our findings through conferences, invited seminars, a TED-Ed video, and outreach activities. Overall, I believe that our research has generated significant impact by shifting the paradigm of several research fields, cultivating the next generation of scientists, and educating the general public.
